item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“Iamadam, post:14, topic:141018”]Odd.
Well, I’m probably missing something stupid - but the problem seems to be coming from you closing the Scanner, and then creating another one with the same input source.

[code]import java.util.Scanner;

public class Measurements {

 static String hello1 = "";
 static String hello2 = "";

public static void main(String[] args) {
	hello1 = value1();
 	System.out.println("You have chosen " + hello1);
	hello2 = value2();
	System.out.println("You are converting " + hello1 + " to " + hello2 + ".");
 }

public static String value1() {
Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);
System.out.println("What are you converting? ");
System.out.println("Type one of the following and press enter: ");
System.out.println(“cm”);
System.out.println(“m”);
System.out.println(“inch”);
String value1 = input.next();
//input.close();
return value1;
}

public static String value2() { 
	System.out.println("What are you converting " + hello1 + " to?");
	Scanner input = new Scanner(System.in);    	
	String value2 = input.nextLine();
	input.close();
	return value2;
}

}[/code]
If the Scanner isn’t closed in the ‘value1’ method, it seems to work fine. Which is weird, because they are two completely different Scanners.
No idea though.[/quote]
Closing something will close underlying streams as well (in this case, System.in is closed along with the Scanner object as it is the underlying stream being used by the Scanner).
Most of the time it’s a good thing, because you don’t have to make a whole bunch of method calls to close all of the underlying streams. In this case, it obviously isn’t.

just as som advice…in your valueX() functions, pass a single scanner object so you don’t have to keep redeclaring them (just to write less repetitive code). So for example:

   String hello2 = value2(in);

}
